author: By Joel Wolfram, Ana Ionova and Campbell Robertson
title: Manhunt Intensifies as Escaped Pennsylvania Prisoner Remains at Large
description: The search is focused on an area near a sprawling botanical garden in the suburbs of Philadelphia. A guard who failed to notice the escapee was fired by the prison.
content: The manhunt for an escaped fugitive in the Philadelphia suburbs appeared to escalate on Friday afternoon as attention focused on the area around a sprawling botanical garden where the escapee had been seen twice in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim, Richard Pérez-Peña and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Elon Musk Refused to Enable Ukraine Drone Attack on Russian Fleet
description: News that Mr. Musk did not allow the use of his Starlink satellite network highlights concerns in Kyiv and Washington about his outsize influence in the war.
content: Elon Musk foiled an attack on Russia’s Black Sea fleet last year by refusing to let Ukraine use his satellite network to guide its drones, Mr. Musk has acknowledged, provoking a furious response from a top official in Kyiv and renewing questions about the global power wielded by a multibillionaire businessman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Automakers and U.A.W. Remain Far Apart as Contract Deadline Nears
description: The United Auto Workers has said it is prepared to strike at General Motors, Ford and Stellantis if a deal is not reached before current contracts end on Thursday.
content: The United Auto Workers union and the three established U.S. automakers remain far apart on wages and other issues with less than a week to go before contracts covering 150,000 union workers expire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why 24 Pianists Are Playing the Same Piece 840 Times
description: A French composer specified that his composition be repeated hundreds of times. His wishes will be followed at N.Y.U. today.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at why 24 pianists will spend all day today — and at least part of tonight — playing the same piece a total of 840 times. We’ll also get details on Mayor Eric Adams’s latest comments on the migrant crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: With ‘Jawan’ and ‘Pathaan,’ Shah Rukh Khan Thrills Bollywood Fans
description: The superstar has led two hit Hindi-language movies this year after a break from starring roles.
content: Bollywood fans flocked to theaters when Shah Rukh Khan returned to a starring role in January after a four-year hiatus. That film, “Pathaan,” has made nearly $130 million, more than the Jennifer Lawrence comedy “No Hard Feelings” and “Air,” the Nike tale starring Matt Damon and Ben Affleck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriella Ferrigine
title: ‘You Wanted to Know Where the Towers Had Gone’
description: After the horror of the World Trade Center attacks, I still had my mom. Did I even have the right to grieve?
content: On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, my mother, Michaela Ferrigine — a stock exchange trader only five days back from maternity leave after the birth of my sister Olivia — had been scheduled to go to a meeting on a high floor of the south tower of the World Trade Center. But the night before, the meeting was postponed. She went instead to her office at 111 Broadway, the Trinity Building, next to the towers. She was there when jihadists plunged the first plane into the north tower, and along with everyone else in her building, she fled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan and Melody Melamed
title: How Did Vanilla Become a Byword for Blandness?
description: The spice is one of the world’s most elusive, complex and hard to cultivate ingredients. But for many Americans, it still represents a “boring” choice.
content: IF, PRESENTED WITH all the ice cream flavors in the world, you ask for vanilla, you are making a declaration: “Not for me a life of adventure. I choose the road more taken.” This is the default, the dead end, where imagination is extinguished. In idiomatic usage, per the dictionary, “vanilla” (or, more damningly, “plain vanilla,” as if that were not redundant) means “having no special or extra features.” So: the bare minimum, the absence of flourish, the annihilation of fun — buttoned-up and bougie, innocuousness incarnate. In a word, a bore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Wisconsin Republicans Try to Subvert Democracy, Again
description: An elected judge could curtail their power, so they want to impeach her.
content: For a little while this year, it looked as though Wisconsin voters had finally broken out of the straitjacket of minority rule in their state. The key to their freedom was an April State Supreme Court election that, turning on the intertwined issues of abortion and gerrymandering, flipped control of the bench from conservatives to liberals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: William Phillips, Who Exposed Corruption in Police Ranks, Dies at 92
description: He was a star witness in televised hearings in New York. He was then convicted of murder and spent decades in prison saying he’d been framed for speaking out.
content: In criminal justice circles, they still debate the case of the New York City police officer William R. Phillips. He was a star witness at televised hearings in 1971 that exposed pervasive police corruption in New York City. But he was then convicted of killing two people and went to prison for 32 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Short-Handed Americans Lose to Germany in World Cup Semifinals
description: The Americans, perennial favorites but without many top N.B.A. stars, were stopped short of the gold medal game. The team will look much different at the Paris Olympics.
content: As the final buzzer sounded Friday night, the American players looked dejected. Hands on hips. Jerseys over faces. Sagging shoulders. Expressions of disbelief as they watched Germany’s players leap and hug in celebration at midcourt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang and Stanley Reed
title: Hundreds Halt Work at Energy Plants in Australia
description: The labor action at liquefied natural gas plants, responsible for about 6 percent of the world’s supply of the fuel, came as talks over pay and work conditions stalled.
content: Hundreds of people at Chevron’s liquefied natural gas plants in Western Australia halted work on Friday, an industrial action affecting two giant projects that account for about 6 percent of the world’s supply of the essential fuel, prompting prices to move higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: verdant
description: This word has appeared in 128 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word verdant has appeared in 128 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 5 in “In the Azores: Earth, Water, Fire and Air, Sometimes All at Once” by Amy Thomas:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Comita
title: Carrie Mae Weems and George C. Wolfe on Defiance and Claiming Space
description: Two creative people in two different fields in one wide-ranging conversation. This time: the “Kitchen Table Series” artist and the theater and film director.
content: George C. Wolfe can pinpoint the exact moment that sparked his career as a director and dramatist. When he was a fourth grader, his all-Black elementary school in Kentucky was preparing for a visit to a nearby white school to mark what was then known as Negro History Week. “We were supposed to sing this song,” recalls Wolfe, 68. “And our principal told us that when we got to a certain line, we should sing it with full conviction because it would shatter all the racism in the room.” To this day, he can remember standing with his classmates singing, “These truths we are declaring, that all men are the same,” and then suddenly belting out, “that liberty’s a torch burning with a steady flame.” “That’s why I’m a storyteller,” he says. “Because someone told me when I was 10 that if I fully committed with my passion and my intelligence and my heart to a line, I could change people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: A Portrait Miniature Was Muse to Mickalene Thomas
description: At Yale University Art Gallery, the artist designs a show blending fact and speculation about the lives of Black Americans whose stories have largely been lost.
content: An exquisite portrait miniature of Rose Prentice, a domestic worker in her Sunday best, painted around 1837, joins the constellation of proud, self-possessed Black women to have served as muse to the artist Mickalene Thomas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Meeting of World Leaders, With Two Major Absences
description: Also, Olivia Rodrigo’s new album. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: President Biden arrived today in New Delhi for the Group of 20 summit, where the world leaders not in the room at the meeting this weekend may be as important as those who are there. China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir Putin of Russia both decided to skip this year’s event, leaving a hole that the U.S. is seeking to fill.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 8, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Sept. 8, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about the Sotheby’s auction of Freddie Mercury’s things misstated the duration of the sale. It ran for more than four hours, not for more than four and a half hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Subtlety of J.R.R. Tolkien
description: Does ‘The Lord of the Rings’ paint exclusively in black and white?
content: Last week marked the 50th anniversary of the death of J.R.R. Tolkien, a date which yielded a spate of memorializing essays. I didn’t write one because although I’m currently reading “The Lord of the Rings” aloud to kids two and three — this is the second time through, with at least one more ahead for kid No. 4 — I’m not a true enough Tolkienphile to be automatically aware of such anniversaries in advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: How a Company That Makes Gun Safes Angered Gun Owners
description: Liberty Safe faced intense criticism this week after it acknowledged that it had voluntarily given the F.B.I. the access code to a safe in response to a search warrant for a property.
content: Liberty Safe, which calls itself “America’s #1 heavy-duty home and gun safe manufacturer,” came under intense criticism from gun owners and conservative commentators this week after it acknowledged that it had voluntarily given the F.B.I. the access code to one of its safes to help in an investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Alito Rejects Calls for Recusal After Interviews in Wall Street Journal
description: The justice dismissed demands from Democratic legislators that he recuse himself from a pending case involving a lawyer who interviewed him.
content: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. on Friday rejected demands from Democratic lawmakers that he recuse himself from a coming tax case after a lawyer involved in the matter interviewed him for The Wall Street Journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Here Are the 20 Oldest Members of Congress
description: Congress has long been an institution that runs on seniority and rewards longevity, and these veteran lawmakers are still running the country at an age when most people are well into retirement.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the 81-year-old longtime Republican leader, has batted away questions about his health after twice freezing on camera, insisting he has no plans to step down ahead of schedule as the leader of his party in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ho-Fung Hung
title: Young People in China Can’t Find Work, and Xi Jinping Has Only One Response
description: Political repression can’t save the Chinese economy.
content: In August the Chinese government released a shocking piece of data: A record 21.3 percent of Chinese citizens between the ages of 16 and 24 in cities were unemployed. It promptly decided to suspend future publication of its urban youth unemployment rate. The current data is bad enough; it’s about the same youth unemployment rate across the Middle East on the eve of the Arab Spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Asome
title: In an English Village, a Home Where the 1430s and the 1970s Peacefully Coexist
description: When the artist Sarah Kaye Rodden and her family took over a former medieval meeting hall in Kent, they chose to honor its many lives.
content: It isn’t unusual for a passer-by to mistake the home of the British artist Sarah Kaye Rodden for a shop. The 15th-century house sits on a bustling high street in the English village of Brasted, in rural Kent, and people are often lured inside by the distinctive objects she keeps near the entrance:a 1930s Belgian oak drawing board, a slatted chair by the Danish Modernist designer Grete Jalk and several of the artist’s own minimalist constructions made from paper, rubber and leather. “I have to tell them that this is my home, and then they back away sheepishly,” says Kaye Rodden, 48. Completed in 1430, the original timber-frame building, which once served as a medieval meeting hall, was in fact repurposed as an antiques store in the 19th century, and its large Victorian front window still seems to promise that rare treasures might be found inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include films with complex schemes, vengeful spouses and plenty of brawling.
content: Jodi (Hailey Kilgore) is working her late shift at a gas station when a biker in a helmet enters to rob the joint. The biker kills a Black customer in a cowboy hat before fleeing into the night. Jodi appears shocked. But she shouldn’t be. The thief is her boyfriend, Eddie (David Iacono). They’re in cahoots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Is Full of Risks. So Why Can’t Corporate America Leave?
description: Doing business in China, once seen as a can’t-miss opportunity, poses a troubling quandary: Reasons to stay can be as compelling as the reasons to retreat.
content: For decades, America’s corporate chieftains saw China as a money spinner. They gushed about its hundreds of millions of consumers, called it “one of the biggest opportunities” and made predictions that this would be “China’s century.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Phone. Keys. Wallet … Brain?
description: Some memory lapses are a normal part of brain function, experts say.
content: I was in the supermarket recently when a woman came running toward me. “Jancee!” she said. “How are you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Louisiana Grand Jury Indicts Retired Priest on Sex Abuse Charges
description: The long-sought charges against Lawrence Hecker come after public allegations that leaders in the Archdiocese of New Orleans knew about accusations against him for decades.
content: A state grand jury in Louisiana has indicted a retired Roman Catholic priest on multiple felony charges related to claims that he sexually assaulted a teenage boy in the 1970s. The long-sought charges come after public allegations that leaders in the Archdiocese of New Orleans knew about accusations against the priest for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Is the Fiscal Picture Getting Better or Worse? Yes.
description: Complicated stories on the deficit front.
content: A decade ago the U.S. political and media establishment was obsessed with budget deficits. This obsession did a lot of harm, helping to deprive the economy of fiscal support after the 2008 financial crisis and keeping unemployment unnecessarily high for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Is Online Learning Effective?
description: A new report found that the heavy dependence on technology during the pandemic caused “staggering” education inequality. What was your experience?
content: During the coronavirus pandemic, many schools moved classes online. Was your school one of them? If so, what was it like to attend school online? Did you enjoy it? Did it work for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says Its New Submarine Can Launch Nuclear Missiles
description: South Korea’s military expressed skepticism, saying that the converted Soviet-era submarine “doesn’t look capable of normal operation.”
content: North Korea said on Friday that its first submarine capable of launching nuclear missiles was now operational, a development that would give the country a new, harder-to-detect means of launching a nuclear strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: A U.S. citizen is among Navalny supporters detained in Russia.
description: The American was accused of donating money to the jailed opposition leader’s Anti-Corruption Foundation, which the Russian government considers an extremist organization.
content: Law enforcement agents in Russia have detained two Americans in separate incidents in recent weeks — one a Russian-born English teacher who was a vocal supporter of the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, and a second man who Russian authorities said was caught trying to smuggle his young son out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Panel Recommended Charging Dozens, Including Lindsey Graham, in Trump Case
description: A special grand jury made the recommendation last year after hearing from dozens of witnesses on whether Donald J. Trump and his allies interfered in the 2020 election.
content: A special grand jury that investigated election interference allegations in Georgia last year recommended indicting more than twice as many Trump allies as prosecutors eventually sought to charge, including Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, the former senators David Perdue and Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, and Michael Flynn, a former national security adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Murder Suspect Is Missing After Escape From D.C. Hospital
description: The authorities are searching for Christopher Haynes, who, the police said, assaulted an officer and fled from a hospital where he had been taken for treatment.
content: The authorities in Washington, D.C., were still searching on Friday for a murder suspect who escaped from custody on Wednesday after he assaulted an officer who was changing his handcuffs at a hospital, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Zach Bryan Arrested After Interfering With Traffic Stop in Oklahoma
description: “Emotions got the best of me and I was out of line in the things I said,” the singer-songwriter wrote on social media.
content: The singer-songwriter Zach Bryan was arrested and briefly jailed in rural Oklahoma on Thursday, a few days after he reached a career milestone by landing both the No. 1 album and single for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rethinking Tammy Wynette and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Trump Civil Trial Scheduled to Last Nearly Three Months
description: The trial, stemming from a lawsuit filed by New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, against the former president, is scheduled to start in October and last almost until Christmas.
content: Donald J. Trump’s coming civil fraud trial, which stems from a lawsuit filed by the New York State attorney general against the former president and his family business, may last nearly three months, according to the state court judge who will preside over the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Jonathan Weisman
title: Manchin Mulls His Political Future, Keeping Washington Guessing
description: The West Virginia Democrat could run for re-election to the Senate, make a third-party presidential bid or simply retire from politics. To his party’s consternation, he’s not ready to say which.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III, the conservative West Virginia Democrat, was attending an event in his home state last month when he made a joke that quickly touched off the latest round of feverish speculation about his political future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: The Teacher Behind the World’s Great Conductors
description: At 93, the Finnish classical music eminence Jorma Panula has generations of students spread around the globe, with more on the way.
content: “He doesn’t like talking about himself,” Marja Kantola-Panula said, gesturing to her husband, Jorma Panula, across their dining table while he sat silently. He had been asked a question about his sprawling presence in classical music as arguably the world’s most influential conducting teacher. But instead of answering, he took a bite from a pastry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: When These Opposites Met, They Found Balance in Each Other
description: Jessica Bendit and Dickran Jebejian grew close despite different backgrounds and being polar opposites in almost every significant way.
content: In September 2018, when Jessica Friedman Bendit and Dickran Walter Jebejian first met, they knew they would be just friends. They were newly-enrolled graduate students in the Luskin School of Public Affairs at the University of California, Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: F.A.A. Spells Out Needed Fixes for SpaceX’s Starship Rocket
description: The agency closed an investigation into what went wrong during an April flight of the massive spacecraft that NASA will rely on to land astronauts on the moon.
content: The next giant Starship rocket from Elon Musk’s SpaceX is standing on the launching pad in South Texas. But the Federal Aviation Administration said on Friday that the company must undertake “corrective actions” before it would issue a launch license for the second flight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Mother Is a Hoarder. Do I Have to Help Her?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on caring for a parent in crisis.
content: My mother and I have a strained relationship because of her myriad mental-health challenges. Our communication is not great; she lacks self-awareness and can’t tolerate any suggestions that force her to face her flaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Peter Baker
title: At G20 in India, Biden Looks to Fill a Hole Left by Putin and Xi
description: With the Russian and Chinese leaders absent, the president hopes to get others to align with him on a variety of matters, including Ukraine and curbing Beijing’s assertiveness in the Indo-Pacific.
content: President Biden arrived in New Delhi on Friday for a global summit meeting where he will present the United States as an economic and strategic counterweight to China and Russia, taking advantage of the absence of leaders from those two countries, who are skipping the gathering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Stopping Tennis to Call Attention to Climate Change
description: Protesters have thrown mashed potatoes at a Monet, interrupted fancy galas and blocked commuter routes in efforts to prompt action on global warming.
content: The environmental activists who delayed the U.S. Open semifinal Thursday night by staging protests in Arthur Ashe Stadium join a long line of high-profile public disruptions aimed at drawing attention to the existential threat posed by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: What to Know About the Anime Coco Gauff Watches Before Playing
description: “I watched like four or five episodes of ‘My Hero Academia’ before I played,” she said after advancing to the U.S. Open final.
content: What do the best athletes do in their downtime? Perhaps stretch, strategize on their game, sure. But those really looking to level up take a different approach: watching anime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Vivek Ramaswamy Is a LinkedIn Post Come to Life
description: Running for president is his latest side hustle.
content: Last year, for a column I was writing about the power that large asset managers like BlackRock and Vanguard exert over the global economy, I called up Vivek Ramaswamy. He was delighted to hear from me.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Florida’s Immigration Law May Affect Hurricane Cleanup
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 8, 2023.
content: “We lost everything we owned. The only saving grace was those guys who came to my house.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Stephen King Explains Why He’s a Mystery Writer Not So Big on Mystery
description: The author discusses his new novel, “Holly,” his views on writing and life, and his own influence on younger generations. And we look at September books.
content: Stephen King’s new novel, “Holly,” is his sixth book to feature the private investigator Holly Gibney, who made her debut as a mousy side character in the 2014 novel “Mr. Mercedes” and has become more complicated and interesting with each subsequent appearance. King appears on the podcast this week to tell the host Gilbert Cruz about Holly’s hold on his imagination and the ways she overlaps with parts of his own personality. Along the way, he also tells a dad joke, remembers his friend Peter Straub, and discusses his views on writing and life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt
title: Democracy’s Assassins Always Have Accomplices
description: The conservative parties in Spain and Brazil could show the G.O.P. a thing or two about how to deal with would-be authoritarians.
content: During the first Republican debate of the 2024 presidential primary campaign last month, Donald Trump’s rivals were asked to raise their hands if they would support his candidacy, even if he was “convicted in a court of law.” Mr. Trump’s effort to overturn the 2020 election wasn’t just a potential criminal offense. It also violated the cardinal rule of democracy: Politicians must accept the results of elections, win or lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: 45 Shows to Watch This Fall
description: Even with much of Hollywood on strike, there will be plenty of notable new and returning shows arriving in the next few months.
content: We’ve been here before. In 2020, to be exact, when it was the pandemic that played havoc with fall network television schedules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Islamists Kill Dozens of Civilians and Soldiers in Two Attacks in Mali
description: The government declared three days of mourning after the attacks on a passenger ferry and a military camp. At least 49 civilians and 15 soldiers were killed.
content: Islamist militants staged separate attacks on a passenger ferry and a military camp in northern Mali on Thursday, the government said, killing dozens of civilians and soldiers in a region of the West African nation that is increasingly controlled by armed groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justice Dept. Asks Supreme Court to Hear Abortion Pill Case
description: The case sets up a showdown before the court on the availability of the most common method of terminating pregnancies.
content: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court on Friday evening to hear a challenge to the availability of a commonly used abortion pill, raising the possibility that the justices will rule on the fate of the drug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 5 Recap: A Plan Starts to Form
description: Half the traders at Prince Cap became involved in a plot against their boss. They just didn’t know it.
content: Let’s do a little narrative reverse engineering, shall we?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: The Rolling Stones Roar Back, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Allison Russell, Cardi B featuring Megan Thee Stallion, Ashley McBryde and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: A Long Walk on a Small(ish) Island
description: On Prince Edward Island, in eastern Canada, a writer finds her rhythm, along with equal parts solitude and camaraderie, as she treks from inn to inn on part of a new 435-mile trail.
content: Never underestimate the difficulty of a flat trail over a great distance. After my first five-hour day following the Island Walk, a new 435-mile trail that rings Prince Edward Island, in Canada’s smallest province, I limped into Points East Coastal Inn in bayside St. Peter’s Bay with a blister cooking on my right sole and a paralyzing need to rest barefoot until checkout the next morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Olivia Rodrigo Has Seen the World Now, and She’s Livid
description: On her second album, “Guts,” which flaunts rock brashness and singer-songwriter intimacy, the sudden pop star is showing just how fraught life is at the top.
content: One of the fundamental conditions — or is it goals? — of pop stardom is hiding the work. You may see Beyoncé sweat, or note how Taylor Swift’s real-life travails inform her artistic choices, but the music created by the most famous performers in pop rarely refers back to the costs, literal and emotional, of making it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Vietnam and U.S. Forge Deeper Ties as Worries Rise About China
description: President Biden is expected to celebrate a new upgrade in relations with Vietnam this weekend, despite concerns about the country’s authoritarian crackdown and repression.
content: When President Biden arrives in Vietnam on Sunday, he is set to celebrate a new phase in the Washington-Hanoi relationship that would bring two historical foes closer than they’ve ever been, drawn together by China’s mounting ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Offscreen, They Got Their Perfect Ending
description: When KJ Smith and Skyh Black first met on the set of the TV show “Sistas,” Covid precautions kept them apart. After exchanging numbers months later, their story extended beyond the screen.
content: In July 2020, KJ Smith, an actress and producer, was excited to get back to Atlanta. Ms. Smith plays Andrea Barnes, one of the lead characters on Tyler Perry’s BET comedy-drama, “Sistas,” which had pushed back shooting because of the pandemic. The cast and crew were filming new episodes, and Ms. Smith had decided to vlog her experience returning to a television set in the midst of Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: Rescuers Blast Open Passages to Extract Sick Explorer From Cave
description: Mark Dickey, an American, became ill 3,400 feet underground in a cave in Turkey. International crews have gathered to help, but it will take time to carry him out.
content: Efforts to extract an American explorer who became ill more than 3,400 feet underground in a cave in southern Turkey expanded on Friday, as international rescue teams installed communications equipment and blasted open narrow areas to allow the passage of a stretcher, officials involved in the rescue said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: When ‘the Academic Girl’ Meets ‘the Popular Guy’
description: Ladi Fatade felt an instant attraction to Kimberly Alexander after seeing her dating app profile three years ago. “It gave me a window into her personality,” he said.
content: Kimberly Ann Alexander’s friends had urged her to do some fine-tuning of her Hinge profile when she joined in May 2020. “I kept getting pushback, like, ‘That’s not going to help you get to know anyone,’” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: After Her Husband Died, She Found a Creative Way to Move Forward
description: When the former defense secretary Ashton Carter died, his wife knew she couldn’t stay in their old home. Downsizing became a way of processing grief.
content: When her husband, Ashton B. Carter, the former defense secretary under President Barack Obama, died of a heart attack at home last October, Stephanie Carter was left with many questions about the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard
title: Heat and Hurricanes: What Keeps the N.Y.C. Climate Chief Up at Night
description: “We are in a climate change emergency,” said Rohit T. Aggarwala. “And two things are unhelpful in an emergency: Panic and despair.”
content: As New York City’s chief climate officer, Rohit T. Aggarwala oversees a slowly sinking metropolis surrounded by water, with an aging sewer system, little tree canopy, paved over natural resources, congestion, and over eight million residents. Sometimes the air turns orange. Sometimes neighborhoods flood. Sometimes the power goes out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Nicholas Fandos
title: G.O.P. Gets the Democratic Border Crisis It Wanted
description: The strain of migrants in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and other cities has taxed resources, divided Democrats and put pressure on President Biden to act.
content: When Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas began sending migrants and asylum seekers from the southwestern frontier to New York, Washington and Chicago, he vowed to bring the border to the Democratic cities he said were naïvely dismissing its costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Biden’s Ambitions at the G20, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Elon Musk Acknowledges Withholding Satellite Service to Thwart Ukrainian Attack
description: The Starlink satellite internet service, which is operated by Mr. Musk’s rocket company SpaceX, has been a digital lifeline for soldiers and civilians in Ukraine.
content: A top adviser to Ukraine’s president accused Elon Musk of enabling Russian aggression, after the billionaire entrepreneur acknowledged denying satellite internet service in order to prevent a Ukrainian drone attack on a Russian naval fleet last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: The Best Grape Jelly Is Homemade
description: Concord grape season is a short one, but you can extend it by making this delicious preserve, Yewande Komolafe writes.
content: Food memories can sometimes run backward, to a moment when we first experienced entirely new sensations. This is not that story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Tennis Reporter on Familiar Grounds
description: Matthew Futterman, a Sports journalist, reflects on his many years attending, and later, covering, the Grand Slam tournament in Flushing, Queens.
content: As a reporter who covers tennis for The New York Times, I am often asked which of the four Grand Slam tournaments — the Australian Open, the French Open, Wimbledon or the U.S. Open — is my favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Climate Protesters Were Coming, So the Gardner Museum Locked Down
description: Activists said it would be a “peaceful field trip,” but previous demonstrations around the world that have damaged artworks had already put officials on edge.
content: On Thursday evening, the doors abruptly closed at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. Officials had learned that climate protesters were planning a visit during the hours when the cultural institution offers free admission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Rachel Bloom Enjoys the Ride
description: The writer and actress visits Coney Island as the New York leg of “Death, Let Me Do My Show” arrives Off Broadway.
content: “My grandfather went on this one time,” Rachel Bloom effused on a recent afternoon. “He thought he was going to die.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl, Martha Schwendener, Jillian Steinhauer, Will Heinrich, John Vincler, Seph Rodney and Holland Cotter
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in September
description: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out an exhibition at Mishkin Gallery that pays homage to Puerto Rican art. And at MoMA PS1, in Queens, two artists explore their Aymaran roots.
content: Want to see new art in New York this weekend? Check out an exhibition at Mishkin Gallery that pays homage to Puerto Rican art. And at MoMA PS1, in Queens, two artists explore their Aymaran roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Lockheed Martin, but Make It Fashion
description: The American defense contractor, best known as the world’s largest arms dealer, is getting into the streetwear business.
content: If you’ve spent any time in the military, or around people who have, you’ve likely encountered the merch often given out free at workplace gatherings or sold at convention centers during air and sea expos. Major defense contractors like Raytheon, Boeing and Northrop-Grumman have produced baseball hats, T-shirts and water bottles advertising military-grade weapons like ballistic missiles, rocket-propelled grenades and fighter jets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Medvedev Stuns Alcaraz to Meet Djokovic in U.S. Open Finals
description: Daniil Medvedev upset the reigning champion Carlos Alcaraz in their semifinal, while Novak Djokovic predictably beat Ben Shelton.
content: Just when the U.S. Open was on the verge of its dream weekend, Daniil Medvedev did perhaps the most Medvedev-like thing and messed it all up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Kurt Streeter
title: Protest Stops U.S. Open Semifinal Match
description: The delay of 49 minutes during the match between Coco Gauff and Karolina Muchova was caused by environmental protesters, including one who glued his feet to the ground.
content: The U.S. Open semifinal match on Thursday night between Coco Gauff and Karolina Muchova was delayed by 49 minutes early in the second set by four environmental protesters in the upper levels of Arthur Ashe Stadium who were calling for an end to fossil fuels. One protester glued his bare feet to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: She Had Constant Fevers and Her Feet Were Swelling. What Was It?
description: All her tests were normal. Soon she felt too sick to go to work.
content: “Sweetie,” the 59-year-old woman called out to her son. “Can you take a day off from work and take me to the emergency room at Penn?” She had been having fevers off and on for nearly a year, and she was fed up and a little scared. The first one only lasted a day. A month later another fever hit her, but again it was one day of feeling lousy. When it happened a third time, she made an appointment to see her doctor in Bridgeton, N.J., about 10 miles from the small Jersey town she called home for much of her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: I.R.S. Deploys Artificial Intelligence to Catch Tax Evasion
description: The tax agency is opening examinations into large hedge funds, private equity groups, real estate investors and law firms.
content: The Internal Revenue Service has started using artificial intelligence to investigate tax evasion at multibillion-dollar partnerships as it looks for ways to better police hedge funds, private equity groups, real estate investors and large law firms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: An Extraordinary Men’s Doubles Three-Peat at the U.S. Open
description: Rajeev Ram of the United States and Joe Salisbury of Britain are the first pair to win three straight doubles titles in New York in the Open era.
content: The 2023 U.S. Open has been characterized by the emergence of several young American stars seeking their first major titles. For Rajeev Ram, the veteran American doubles specialist, winning titles here is becoming repetitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Sarah Young, 77, Dies; Created an Empire Around a Christian Devotional
description: Her book “Jesus Calling,” written in the voice of Jesus Christ, rose to the top of the Christian publishing best-seller lists. Sequels and spinoffs followed.
content: Sarah Young, whose book “Jesus Calling,” composed of devotional readings written in the voice of Jesus Christ, sold tens of millions of copies and spawned an evangelical empire of sequels, television shows and podcasts, died on Aug. 31 at her home in Brentwood, Tenn., a suburb of Nashville. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: ‘There Was Definitely a Thumb on the Scale to Get Boys’
description: Declining male enrollment has led many colleges to adopt an unofficial policy: affirmative action for men.
content: In the spring of 2021, about 2,000 students on the campus of Tulane University in New Orleans received an email they were expecting. They had filled out an elaborate survey provided by Marriage Pact, a matchmaking service popular on many campuses, and the day had come for each of them to be given the name of a fellow student who might be a long-term romantic partner. When the results came in, however, about 900 straight women who participated were surprised by what the email offered: a friend match instead of a love interest. The survey was a lark, something most Tulane students saw as an icebreaker more than an important service. But the results pointed to a phenomenon at the school — and at many other schools — that has only grown more pronounced since then, one that affects much more than just students’ social lives: Women now outnumber men on campus, by a wide margin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fiona Mozley
title: Lauren Groff’s Latest Is a Lonely Novel of Hunger and Survival
description: “The Vaster Wilds” follows a girl’s escape from a nameless colonial settlement into the unforgiving terrain of America.
content: Jamestown, Va., the first permanent English settlement in the Americas, very nearly didn’t survive. A few years into its existence, in the early 1600s, the majority of the population had succumbed to famine and disease. The period known as the Starving Time has taken on allegorical status. Jamestown is the colony that tried too much too soon; that underestimated the harsh climate, the foreign land, its existing, Indigenous population. Pilgrims went in search of heaven and found hell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Luke Vander Ploeg, Alex Stern, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: A Tragic Fire and Broken Promises in South Africa
description: The fire that killed at least 76 people in Johannesburg last week is raising questions about chaos and dysfunction in Africa’s richest city.
content: This episode contains descriptions of severe injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Congestion Pricing Is Coming. It Doesn’t Have to Be Painful.
description: There are reasonable concerns about charging drivers to enter Manhattan. But making the borough a playground for the rich isn’t one of them.
content: After years of deliberation, congestion pricing, arriving by way of moral and practical necessity, will be implemented in New York City sometime next year. The urgency would seem to require little in the way of extra evidence. On Wednesday, the United Nations announced that the previous three months have been the world’s hottest on record, with the secretary general telling us what we already understand, that “climate breakdown has begun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Lisa L. Schell
title: One Month After the Lahaina Fire, Families and Residents Seek Closure
description: Many residents have begun to accept that their loved ones will not be coming back, and survivors wonder what comes next.
content: It has been one month since a wind-whipped wildfire engulfed the historic Hawaiian town of Lahaina, and the authorities are still trying to determine exactly how many people died in the nation’s deadliest conflagration in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: What $50 Million Can Buy: Inside the Sleek New White House Situation Room
description: The ultrasecure facility, which was last upgraded in 2006, is returning to use after officials closed it for a year to modernize it in an era of high-tech sparring with China and Russia.
content: The White House Situation Room, the ultrasecure facility known to West Wing insiders simply as “the whizzer,” has undergone a $50 million renovation, with sophisticated communications equipment and technology to prevent American adversaries from listening in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Melissa Clark’s Five-Star Chicken Parm
description: “I made the recipe as-is and it turned out amazing,” a reader says. “I’m in love. Melissa Clark has never steered me wrong.”
content: Hello, all. This is Emily, the editor in chief of Cooking and Food at The New York Times, and I’m here today to talk about my favorite member of the Parm family: chicken Parmesan (above). My heart sings when a bubbling pan of chicken Parm emerges from the oven, the plush cutlets submerged in rust-red sauce, cloaked with melted cheese. The pleasures are a little different from the crisped smush of eggplant Parm; same genre, but another tune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Is Said to Have Told Blake Masters He’d Lose Senate Primary to Kari Lake
description: Neither potential candidate has entered the race to unseat Senator Kyrsten Sinema in Arizona.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday called Blake Masters, the failed Arizona Senate candidate considering a second run next year, and told him he didn’t think Mr. Masters could win a primary race against Kari Lake, the former news anchor who ran unsuccessfully for governor last year, according to two people briefed on the conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wayne Coffey
title: You Know Her Past. Mo’ne Davis Is Working on Her Future.
description: Davis seemed unstoppable at the Little League World Series nine years ago. As she begins graduate school at Columbia, she is still charging ahead.
content: Her sudden sprint to celebrity started on a small mound of dirt in South Williamsport, Pa., 46 feet from home plate, winging 71 mile-per-hour fastballs and sweeping curveballs, braids bouncing behind her as she went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: After Death of Her Mentor, Tahesha Way Is Named N.J. Lieutenant Governor
description: Ms. Way, New Jersey’s secretary of state, was selected for the post after Sheila Y. Oliver, the former lieutenant governor, died in office Aug. 1.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey named his longtime secretary of state, Tahesha L. Way, lieutenant governor on Friday, five weeks after his former second-in-command died in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: D.E.I. Statements Stir Debate on College Campuses
description: Yoel Inbar, a psychology professor, thought he might be teaching at U.C.L.A., but his reservations about diversity statements got him in trouble.
content: Yoel Inbar, a noted psychology professor at the University of Toronto, figured he might be teaching this fall at U.C.L.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Someone Who May Prefer Platonic Relationships
description: Rachel Fabi and Ken Stern open our solving weekend with a puzzle that is the polar opposite of 34-Across.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Qasim
title: Political Histories Refracted Through a Personal Lens
description: New essay collections by Myriam Gurba, Jenn Shapland and Wang Xiaobo treat public and private subjects with invigorating conviction.
content: In 2019, the memoirist and story writer Myriam Gurba wrote a viral essay on Jeanine Cummins’s “American Dirt” in which she excoriates the author for having “identified the gringo appetite for Mexican pain and found a way to exploit it.” In this and 10 other essays included in CREEP: Accusations and Confessions (Avid Reader Press, 332 pp., $27), Gurba writes the personal and political with invigorating conviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: A Sudden Bond Binge on Wall St. Reflects Rising Optimism
description: The rush by companies to borrow comes as fears of a potential recession recede and executives expect interest rates to remain high.
content: Companies have rushed to borrow tens of billions of dollars this week, a sign that optimism about the outlook for the economy is beginning to take hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liza Weisstuch
title: Jobless, Divorced, on Probation; a Pandemic Hobby Turned His Life Around
description: Danny Cortes was at rock bottom when Covid hit. Then a craft hobby to stay sane during lockdown blew up on social media — and in auction houses.
content: In March 2020, Danny Cortes was already facing a crisis — he was out of work, in the middle of a divorce and serving a four-year probation sentence for selling drugs — when Covid hit. He found himself isolated and devoting an unhealthy amount of time to Instagram.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pelosi, Defying Predictions, Says She Will Seek Re-election in 2024
description: Since she stepped down from leadership last year, many observers expected Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to head toward retirement. But she has kept people guessing about her future.
content: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, who served for decades as the Democratic Party’s House leader and was the first woman to become speaker, announced on Friday that she would seek re-election in 2024, ending months of speculation about her political future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Here Are the Most Anticipated Movies of Fall 2023
description: New films by Martin Scorsese, Sofia Coppola, David Fincher and Bradley Cooper lead a select list of the season’s highlights.
content: What’s the anatomy of a fall movie season? Although the writers’ and actors’ strikes have kept Hollywood in suspense, the calendar is, for now, still filled with exciting titles, including work from established masters (Martin Scorsese, Sofia Coppola, David Fincher) and relative breakouts like Justine Triet, the director of, well, “Anatomy of a Fall,” which won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival in May. Here is a select list of features coming to theaters and streaming services beginning later this month. (Pedro Almodóvar and Wes Anderson, among other directors, are releasing shorts but those are not included.) Release dates and platforms are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Court Grants Temporary Stay on Texas’ Buoy Barrier in Rio Grande
description: The barrier was placed by the state to discourage illegal crossings from Mexico.
content: A U.S. appeals court issued an order on Thursday temporarily ensuring that a barrier of floating buoys in the Rio Grande that was placed by Texas to discourage illegal crossings could stay in place while the court considered a full decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At the U.S. Open, the Dwindling Ranks Leave Space and a Solitary Vibe
description: The U.S. Open begins with 128 players in each singles draw, and every day some will lose. Gradually, then suddenly, there’s a lot of space in the locker rooms.
content: It happens every year. Tennis players, by the hundreds, disappear from Flushing Meadows Corona Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Declan Walsh, Eric Schmitt, Vivian Yee and Julian E. Barnes
title: After Prigozhin’s Death, a High-Stakes Scramble for His Empire
description: A shadowy fight is playing out on three continents for control of Yevgeny Prigozhin’s sprawling interests as head of the Wagner mercenary group. The biggest prize: his lucrative operations in Africa.
content: African leaders allied with Russia had grown used to dealing with Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the swaggering, profane mercenary leader who traveled the continent by private jet, offering to prop up shaky regimes with guns and propaganda in return for gold and diamonds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Books That Explain California
description: Readers share the fiction and nonfiction works that shed light on our vast state.
content: For weeks, readers have been sending me great recommendations for books that best explain California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: It Only Seems Like Everything on Streaming Gets Canceled Now
description: Despite high-profile cuts, streaming isn’t as brutal on new shows as network TV was. (But it’s not the paradise we hoped for, either.)
content: It is time that we have a discussion about cancel culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: With ‘Deadlocked,’ Dawn Porter Expands Her Canvas
description: The acclaimed documentarian has generally focused on individuals and small groups. Her new series takes on the history of the Supreme Court.
content: “Deadlocked” is nothing if not ambitious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: The G20 summit in New Delhi.
content: The Group of 20 summit kicks off tomorrow in New Delhi, bringing together world leaders to coordinate policy for the global economy. President Biden is expected to attend, but China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir Putin of Russia will skip the event. Read more about the event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Five Prison Escapes That Captured Public Attention
description: Two high-profile escapes this week — one near Philadelphia and one in London — have led to large-scale manhunts. They’re not the first.
content: As long as there have been prisons, there have been people trying to break out of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis, Leading a State Menaced by Climate Change, Shrugs Off the Threat
description: The Florida governor, who has cast himself as a Teddy Roosevelt-style conservationist, sounds far different as a presidential candidate, pledging to expand fossil fuel production and fight electric-vehicle mandates.
content: During his 2018 run for governor, Ron DeSantis not only pledged to protect Florida’s Everglades and waterways, he also acknowledged that humans played a role in exacerbating the climate change that threatened them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: California Could Become the First State to Ban Caste Bias as Prejudices Linger
description: The bill, which was passed by the State Legislature this week, has led to intense debate among South Asian immigrants.
content: Ramesh Suman, a real estate agent in Antioch, Calif., remembers the client who refused to see a house after saying that it looked like it belonged to members of the Dalit community, a historically oppressed group of people relegated below even the lowest rung of the caste hierarchy once predominant in South Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Dumb Money’ Lampoons Wall Street Titans With a Knowing Eye
description: The film tells the story about the stock market frenzy over the video game retailer GameStop. It was financed and produced by the son of a Wall Street superpower.
content: “Dumb Money” is the kind of midbudget, formula-busting, thinking-person’s movie that isn’t supposed to get made anymore, much less receive a wide, studio-backed release in theaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip-Daniel Ducasse and Jay Massacret
title: Fall Men’s Wear Channels the ’80s, Down to the Skinny Ties and Pleats
description: Billowing high-waisted trousers and asymmetrical silhouettes give this season a vintage flair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Shabtai Shavit, Former Top Israeli Spymaster, Dies at 84
description: As director-general of the Mossad under three prime ministers, he helped orchestrate a treaty between Israel and Jordan. But he also showed an iron hand.
content: Shabtai Shavit, who as director-general of the Israeli intelligence agency the Mossad in the 1990s helped broker a peace agreement with Jordan, oversaw the assassinations of Islamic terrorists and navigated the global fallout from the collapse of the Soviet Union, died on Tuesday during a vacation in Italy. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Deep Dive Into Olivia Rodrigo’s Triumphant ‘Guts’
description: Hear songs from her new LP in conversation with ones from the past.
content: In May 2021, Olivia Rodrigo, then 18 years old, released her debut album, “Sour.” Earlier that year, the singer-songwriter had become an overnight sensation with her heart-tugging, piano-driven ballad “Drivers License,” but “Sour” proved that there was so much more to her than that: She could also pull off dreamy alt-rock (“Deja Vu”), spiky pop-punk (“Good 4 U”) and sharp social commentary (“Jealousy, Jealousy”). In a review I wrote at the time, I noted that “Rodrigo’s songs have lived-in details to spare, as though she had all this time been assembling a detailed dossier on the emotional minutiae of the teenage experience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Judge Denies Meadows’s Request to Move Georgia Case to Federal Court
description: Moving the case to federal court would have given Mark Meadows, a former White House chief of staff, one key advantage: a jury pool that was more favorable to Donald J. Trump.
content: Georgia prosecutors leading the criminal election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and 18 of his allies notched a victory on Friday when a judge rejected an effort by Mark Meadows, Mr. Trump’s former White House chief of staff, to move his case from state court to federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Supreme Court Considers Upholding Abortion Restrictions
description: Several justices questioned whether Florida’s constitutional privacy rights extend to abortion, as has been longstanding legal precedent.
content: The Florida Supreme Court’s conservative justices repeatedly questioned on Friday whether the state’s privacy rights extend to abortion as they considered whether to uphold a ban on the procedure after 15 weeks of pregnancy — a decision that could overturn decades of legal precedent and trigger a far more restrictive ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender and Michael Gold
title: Race to Be Trump’s Running Mate Begins as Noem Endorses Him
description: At a rally on Friday, Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota threw her support behind the former president, whose large lead in polls has stirred speculation about the No. 2 job.
content: Donald J. Trump’s resilience in polls of the Republican presidential primary field is shifting attention to what, for the moment at least, is the only truly competitive national race for 2024: the contest to be his running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Quil Lemons Wants to Be the Robert Mapplethorpe of His Community
description: The photographer’s new exhibition explores Black masculinity and queerness.
content: Growing up in South Philadelphia, Quil Lemons first trained his lens on family and friends, his photographs of cousins and neighbors snaring the art world’s attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Blair
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Philadelphia Police Officer Charged in Fatal Shooting
description: Body camera footage shows a police officer shooting Eddie Irizarry, who had been sitting in a car, at near point-blank range.
content: A Philadelphia police officer was charged with murder after he fatally shot a 27-year-old man who was in his car at near point-blank range, prosecutors announced on Friday, weeks after top police officials announced that body camera footage of the killing showed a different account than what the officer initially described.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Seeking Link to Trump, Prosecutors Questioned Proud Boys Leader
description: Enrique Tarrio said in an interview that prosecutors believed he had communicated with President Donald Trump through intermediaries before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
content: Last October, a few months before he went to trial on sedition charges linked to the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Enrique Tarrio, the former leader of the Proud Boys, got an invitation: The federal prosecutors in charge of his case asked him and his lawyers to sit down for a meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Iverson
title: Easy Mode: Clues for Sept. 8
description: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
content: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: From Rock Star to Bodyguard to Resisting Myanmar’s Coup in Film
description: Lynn Lynn was a musical idol when he volunteered in 2015 to protect the life of Myanmar’s new civilian leader. Forced to flee after 2021’s coup, he has reinvented himself as a film director.
content: Long before he became an award-winning filmmaker, Lynn Lynn was already a star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven McElroy
title: Musicals, Plays and Festivals to Take In This Fall and Spring
description: A starry Sondheim revival on Broadway, Alicia Keys’s new musical and John Turturro in a Philip Roth adaptation: a guide to this season’s theater.
content: In a different reality, this list of show openings across the country might be longer. You’d see the world premiere of Larissa FastHorse’s “Fake It Until You Make It,” for example, one of many productions canceled or postponed because of the powerful economic headwinds that theaters are facing. Still, there’s hope: Exciting ideas are taking shape in regional theaters, where works like “Run Bambi Run,” “Illinois” and “The Salvagers” are being staged. In New York, “Swing State,” “Hell’s Kitchen” and “Sabbath’s Theater” are among the shows that remind us of theater’s promise. And Broadway, of course, with intriguing new shows like “Gutenberg! The Musical,” “I Need That” and “How to Dance in Ohio,” will always survive. (Dates are subject to change.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Culling, Curfews and Caps: Australia ‘Declares War’ on Its Cat Problem
description: Feral cats have long been recognized as a major threat to the continent’s native wildlife. But now the government is also exploring ways to rein in domestic cats.
content: Invasive species are the biggest drivers of biodiversity loss in Australia, a new United Nations report found this week. And feral cats are the most invasive in the country’s landscape, killing an estimated two billion animals per year, according to Australia’s environment minister, Tanya Plibersek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Climate Report Card Says Countries Are Trying, but Urgently Need Improvement
description: The global assessment, two years in the making, is the first official gauge of progress under the 2015 Paris Agreement.
content: Eight years after world leaders approved a landmark agreement in Paris to fight climate change, countries have made only limited progress in staving off the most dangerous effects of global warming, according to the first official report card on the global climate treaty.

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Jewel-Encrusted Ring That Conjures the Spirit of a Black Forest Wedding
description: The Van Cleef & Arpels piece is inspired by an exuberant German bridal crown.
content: One senses that the establishment of Van Cleef & Arpels was preordained. The husband and wife Alfred Van Cleef and Estelle Arpels — the son of a diamond cutter and the daughter of a gemstone dealer — opened the French maison in 1906 in Paris’s First Arrondissement, where they began making wristwatches and jewelry adorned with wood and gems inspired by good luck charms. During the following decades, the brand continued to innovate — inventing the minaudière and creating necklaces that could be worn as bracelets — and in 1933 it introduced the Mystery Setting, in which stones appeared to be invisibly placed without any of their metal fasteners showing. Whimsical designs, which gained a loyal following from the likes of Princess Grace of Monaco and Elizabeth Taylor, took cues from the cosmos, flora and fauna, mythology, poetry, ballet, fairy tales, architecture and Surrealism. In the 1940s and ’50s, Van Cleef & Arpels introduced a collection of dome-like gold rings covered in kaleidoscopic arrays of multicolored jewels.
